title: The mouse Y* chromosome involves a complex rearrangement, including interstitial positioning of the pseudoautosomal region
abstract: Request reprints from Dr. Eva M. Eicher. The Jackson Laboratory. 600 Main Street. Bar Harbor. ME 04609 (USA).

abstract.text: Request reprints from Dr. Eva M. Eicher. The Jackson Laboratory. 600 Main Street. Bar Harbor. ME 04609 (USA).

body_text.text: Abstract. Cytological analysis of the mouse Y* chromosome revealed a complex rearrangement involving acquisition of a functional centromere and centromeric heterochromatin and attachment of this chromosomal segment to the distal end of a normal Y chromosome. This rearrangement positioned the Y short-arm region at the distal end of the Y* chromosome and the pseudoautosomal region interstitially. just distal to the newly acquired centromere. In addition, the majority of the pseudoau tosomal region was inverted. Recombination between the X and the Y* chromosomes generates two new sex chromosomes: (1) a large chromosome comprised of the X chromosome attached at its distal end to all of the Y* chromosome but missing the cen tromeric region (XY*) and (2) a small chromosome containing the centromeric portion of the Y* chromosome attached to Gband-negative material from the X chromosome (Y*x). Mice that inherit the XY' chromosome develop as sterile males, whereas mice that inherit the Y*x chromosome develop as fer tile females. Recovery of equal numbers of recombinant and nonrecombinant offspring from XY* males supports the hy pothesis that recombination between the mammalian X and Y chromosomes is necessary for primary spermatocytes to suc cessfully complete spermatogenesis and form functional sperm.

Studies of the inheritance and developmental consequences of abnormal human and mouse Y chromosomes have been instrumental in subdividing this intriguing mammalian chro mosome into cytologically definable genetic regions (see. e.g.. Eicher and Washburn. 1986; Page et al., 1987; Sinclair et al., 1990) . In this regard, analysis of the Y-chromosome rearrange ment designated as Tp(Y)lCt (sex-reversed, or Sxr; Cattanach et al.. 1971) has facilitated assignment of the following genes or DNA sequences to the short arm of the mouse Y chromosome (McLaren et al.. 1988 : Roberts et al., 1988 : the H-Y antigen (Hya) locus (Bennett et al., 1977; Simpson et al., 1983) , malespecific GATA/GACA repeats (Jones and Singh. 1981; Epplen et al" 1982) , the Y-linked zinc finger protein (Zfy-1 and ZJ'y-2) genes (Page etal.. 1987; Page, 1988 : Mardonet al.. 1989 . and the sex-determining region Y (Sry) gene (Gubbay et al.. 1990; Sinclair et al., 1990) . recently shown to be the Ylinked testis-determining (Tdy) locus (Koopman et al.. 1991) .

We previously reported preliminary observations on another inherited abnormal mouse Y chromosome (Eicher, 1982 Eicher and Washburn. 1986 ). This Y chromosome was of particular interest because the rearrangement of Y chro mosomal material appeared to include transposition of the pseudoautosomal region. Here we present the results of a more extensive investigation of this aberrant chromosome, including verification that the pseudoautosomal region is adjacent to the functional centromere. Chromosomal banding and in situ hy bridization studies indicate that the functional centromere was acquired from another chromosome, possibly the X chromo some. Although the rearranged Y chromosome lacks a cytologi cally detectable short arm. data analyses performed after restric tion-enzyme banding, in situ hybridization, and Southern blot ting indicate that DNA sequences present on the normal Y short arm are located at the distal end of the Y* chromosome. In addi tion. data from Southern blot hybridization with the telomere consensus sequence (TTAGGG) suggest that the normal Y short-arm telomere is present and functions as the distal Y* tel omere. We propose T(XAl?:InY)8Ei as the official name of this aberrant Y chromosome, with Y* ("Y star") as the short-hand designation.

We also present data on the mode of inheritance of the Y* chromosome. These data, together with meiotic data presented in the accompanying paper (Hale et al., 1991) , indicate that germ cells in XY* males develop beyond the first meiotic divi sion only if recombination has occurred between the X and Y* chromosomes.

Mice from the following inbred and Y-consomic inbred strains were used in these studies: LT/SvEi. LT/SvEi-Y*. C57BL/6JEi. and C57BL/6JEi.LT/ SvEi-Y*. For ease of presentation, these strains are hereafter denoted as LT. LT-Y*. B6. and B6.LT-Y*. respectively. The B6.LT-Y* consomic strain was constructed as follows: An XY* male from the LT-Y* strain was mated to a B6 female, and an F| male carrying the Y* chromosome was backcrossed to a B6 female. This method of breeding (i.e., a B6 female mated to an XY* male) was repeated to produce eventually a B6 consomic strain containing the Y* chro mosome. Males from the B6.LT-Y* strain used in this study were at the N 10 or greater generation of backcrossing to B6.
body_text.section: Strains and stocks o f mice

body_text.text: To obtain segregation data for the Y* chromosome, two XY* males from the LT-Y* strain and the B6.LT-Y* strains were mated to normal LT and B6 females, respectively. Individual fetuses at 14.5-17.5 days of development were typed for sex-chromosome composition by analysis of metaphase chro mosomes from liver. In another experiment, three XY* males, produced by crossing a B6 female with an XY* male from the LT-Y* strain, were mated to B6 females. Offspring at 3-6 wk of age were typed for sex-chromosome com position by analysis of metaphase preparations from bone marrow.

Metaphase chromosomes were ohtained from mitogen-stimulated lym phocyte cultures (Davisson and Akeson. 1987) . bone marrow-, and fetal liver (Eicher and Washburn. 1978) . G-banding was accomplished as described by Eicher and Washburn ( 1978) . C-banding was conducted using a modification of the method developed by Sumner ( 1972) . T reatment of melaphase chromo somes with Ahtl followed the procedure of Kaclbling et al. ( 1984) .

Fluorescence in situ hybridization was performed using mitotic chromo somes prepared from mitogen-stimulated lymphocyte cultures from LT and LT-Y* mice. The position of the pseudoautosomal region on the Y* chromo some was determined using the DNA clone pMov-15/1. which contains a sequence flanking the Mov-15 locus, a Moloney murine leukemia virus inserted into the pseudoautosomal region of the Y chromosome (Harbers et al., 1986) .

Two DNA probes were used to determine whether specific sequences were present al the centromere of the Y* chromosome. One probe. pMSat5. is a 1.4-kb Avail fragment containing five tandem repeats of the mouse major satellite DNA sequence (Varmuzaet al.. 1988 ). This sequence is located at the centromcric region of all mouse chromosomes except the Y (Jones. 1970; Pardue and Gall. 1970: Redi et al.. 1990 ). The other probe. 70-38. contains an X-chromosome-derivcd 9.0-kb EcoRl fragment that hybridizes to repetitive sequences located at the boundary-between regions XA1 and XA2 (Disteche et al.. 1987 (Disteche et al.. . 1989 ). The pErs5A-4/680 probe was used to locate repeated GATA/GACA sequences normally present on the short arm of the Y (see also Nanda et al.. 1990 ). This probe contains a 680-bp ///«dlll/EcoRI fragment isolated from pErsSA. including all but two base pairs from positions 1225 to 1907 (Epplen et al.. 1982) .

Purified insert DNA was biotinylated using the Oncor Non-Isotopic Sys tem for DNA probe labeling. Following nick translation, the labeled insert was separated from unincorporated nucleotides on a Sephadex G-50 spin column and diluted to a concentration of I pg/100 pi in 2 mM EDTA. Melaphase chromosomes were prepared for hybridization using the reagents and proto cols provided in the Oncor Chromosome In Situ Kit. Labeled inserts from pMov-l 5/1, pMSat5, and 70-38 were hybridized to metaphase chromosomes for 15-20 h at 37 °C under the conditions specified in the Oncor Chromo some In Situ Kit (65% formamide, 10% dextran sulfate. 2 x SSC. 100 pg/ml sheared herring sperm DNA). The slides were then washed in 65% formamidc. 2 x SSC at 41-43 °C. Insert from pErs5A-4/680 was hybridized for 14-16 h in 50% formamide. 10% dextran sulfate. 2 x SSC at 37 °C. and the slides were then washed in 50% formamide. 2 x SSC at 39 °C.

Hybridization was detected with fluorescein-labeled avidin and one to two amplifications with antiavidin antibody (Oncor). The chromosomes were then counterstained with propidium iodide in antifade medium. Fluo rescein and propidium iodide fluorescence were excited at 450-490 nrn (Zeiss filter combination No. 09) with a Zeiss epifluorescence microscope equipped with a 50-W high-pressure mercury-lamp.

Prior to hybridization, metaphase chromosomes were located by phasecontrast microscopy. Follow ing hybridization, metaphase chromosomes were relocated and photographed with Kodaeolor 400 film at exposure times of 20-45 s. The coverslip and propidium iodide/antifade mixture were then rinsed from the slides, and the preparations were treated for C-banding. Mela phase chromosomes were relocated to verify the chromosome identification, determine the position of the centromere, and ascertain the location of the hybridization signals.

Five DNA probes were used: (1) pYBlO contains a 305-bp repetitive sequence isolated from an EcoRl partial-digest Charon 4A library of genomic C57BL/I0 male DNA. pYBIO hybridizes only to DNA from males of species belonging to the subgenus Mas, genus Mas (Eicher et al.. 1989) . (2) pErs5A-4/680 (see above) hybridizes to DNA sequences containing GATA/GACA repeats. (3) pCRY8/B contains a 2.2-kb /-.'coRI sequence isolated from a flowsorted. mouse Y-enrichcd library. pCRY8/B detects Y-specific sequences within the region defined by 5.w (Bishop et al.. 1987) . (4) pCMPXY I contains a unique 1.3-kb sequence isolated from the human Y chromosome (Mitchell el al.. 1989 ) that includes the human zinc finger sequence identified by Page el al. (1987) . At low-stringency hybridization conditions. pCMPXY I detects two mouse Y-derived loci (Zfy-l and Zfy-2). as well as an X-dcrived locus f'/.fx) and a Chromosome 10-derived locus (7fa) (Mitchell et al.. 1989) . Zfy-l and Zfy-2 are located in the region of the normal Y chromosome defined by S a t (Page et al., 1987) . (5) (TTAGGG)6 is a synthetic oligonucleotide contain ing six copies of the telomere consensus sequence TTAGGG (Movzis et al., 1988) . (TTAGGGV, identifies a number of telomere-related sequences from the mouse genome, including two male-specific fragments: a 14-kb Ddel frag ment (Elliott and Yen. 1991) and an 18-kb I find fragment (unpublished data), both of w-hich are probably derived from the short-arm telomere of the Y chromosome.
body_text.section: Probes used in Southern blot analysis

body_text.text: DNA was isolated from spleens obtained from LT and LT-Y* mice by the method of Jenkins el al. ( 1982) . Seven to ten micrograms of each DNA sample were digested with the appropriate restriction endonuclease (see legend of Fig. 3 ) under the conditions recommended by the supplier (BRL), electrophoresed through 1% agarose (Seakem. FMC Corp.), and transferred to Zeta-Probe nylon filters (Bio-Rad Laboratories) by blotting overnight in 0.4 M NaOH (Reed and Mann. 1985) . For analysis with the telomere consensus probe, digested DNAs were electrophoresed through 0.6% agarose. Used fil ters were stripped of labeled probe by two successive 20-min washes in a 0 .1 x SSC. 0 .1 % SDS solution at 95 °C and reprobed as described below.
body_text.section: DNA isolation and Southern blot analysis

body_text.text: Filters to be hybridized with pYBIO. pErs5A-4/680. pCRY8/B. or PCMPXY I were prewashed in 0.1 x SSC, 0.5% SDS for I h at 65 °C and then incubated in 100 ml of prehybridization solution containing 4 x SSCP (480 mM NaCI. 60 mM sodium citrate. 60 mM Na^HPOa. 18 mM NaH^POj). lOx Denhardt's solution (0.2% Ficoll. 0.2% polyvinylpyrrolidone. 0.2% bovine serum albumin), and 1.0% SDS for 4 h at 65 °C. Probes pCRY8/B and pCMPXY 1 were nick-translated according to Rigby el al. (1977) with [ct-3-P]dCTP (3.000 Ci/mM) to a specific activity of > 2 x 10s cpm/pg. Probes pYBlOand pErs5A-4/680 were labeled with [a-'-P]dCTP (3.000 Ci/mM) to a specific activity of > 5 x 10* cpm/pg using a T4 polymerase kit (BRL). Prehy bridized filters were hybridized overnight at 65 °C with 1-5 x I06 cpm/ml of denatured, 3:P-labcled probe in 20 ml of hybridizing solution (4 x SSCP. 2 x Denhardt's solution. 1 % SDS. 100 pg/ml denatured sonicated salmon sperm DNA). For pErs5A-4/680. salmon sperm DNA was excluded from the hybrid ization solution. After hybridization, the filters were washed using the follow ing solutions and temperatures: 0 .1 x SSC. 0 .1 % SDS. 65 °C for pYBIO: 4 x SSC, 0.1 % SDS. 65 °C for pErs5A-4/680 and pCRY8/B: and 1 x SSC. 0.1 % SDS. 55 °C for pCMPXY I.
body_text.section: DNA isolation and Southern blot analysis

body_text.text: Filters to be hybridized with (TTAGGQs were prehybridized for 4 h at 50°C in a solution containing 10 x Denhardt's solution. 0.5% SDS. 10% dextran sulfate. 5 x SSCP. Hybridization was performed overnight al 50 °C in fresh prehybridi/.ation buffer containing 25 pmol of probe labeled with 150 pCi of (7-32P]ATP using 20 units of T4 polynucleotide kinase (BRL) in the recommended buffer. Hybridized filters were washed al 50 °C in three changes of 4 x SSC, 0 .1 % SDS for 15 min each.
body_text.section: DNA isolation and Southern blot analysis

body_text.text: Kig. 1. Cytological analysis of mitotic mctaphase chromosomes from XY. XY*. XY*X. and XXV' mice. G-banded metaphase chromosomes from (a) XXV' male (arrow designates XY' chromosome) w ith (b) enlargement of sex chromosomes, (c) XY*X female (arrow designates Y*x chromosome) with (d) enlargement of sex chromosomes, (e) G-banded Y and Y* chromosomes with Chromosomes 19 included for comparison. Note the extensive amount of centromcric heterochromatin and distinct G-banding pattern of the Y* chro mosome. (f) C-banded Y. Y*. XY" . and Y*x chromosomes. Note the evidence of a short arm (arrowhead) on the normal Y chromosome and the presence of centromeric hetcrochromatin on the Y*. XY\ and Y*x chromosomes, (g) .(/¡d-banded Y. Y*. XY\ and Y*x chromosomes. Note the small arm (arrow head) present on the normal Y chromosome and the small, darkly staining region, representing the original Y short arm. present at the distal end of the Y* and XY* chromosomes (arrowheads). A negatively stained region (not observable on these preparations) is sometimes seen just proximal to the darkly stained region.
body_text.section: DNA isolation and Southern blot analysis

body_text.text: Autoradiography was performed using Kodak XAR-5 film for 1-5 days at -7()°C with DuPont Cronex intensifying screens, except for filters hybrid ized with the pErs5A-4/680and(TTAGGG),, probes, for w hich the films were exposed for 6-48 h without intensifying screens.
body_text.section: DNA isolation and Southern blot analysis

body_text.text: During the construction of an LT congenic strain carry ing the Pgk-la allele at the X-linked phosphoglycerate kinase-1 (Pgk-1) locus (Eppig and Eicher. 1983) . several offspring with unexpected PGK-1 phenotypes were noted in a trio mating involving two Pgk-I"/Pgk-Ih females of the ninth backcross gen eration (N9) mated to an LT (Pgk-lb) male. These abnormal offspring included PGK-1 A females and PGK-1 AB males. Nor mal female (PGK-1 AB and PGK-1B) and male (PGK-1 A and PGK-1 B) sibs were also identified. Cytological analysis revealed that the abnormal males possessed 40 chromosomes, including a normal X chromosome and a very large chromosome ( Fig. 1 a,  b ). These males had small testes and were sterile. The chromo some complement of the exceptional females also contained 40 chromosomes, including a normal X chromosome and a very small chromosome ( Fig. lc. d) . These females were fertile and transmuted the small chromosome to their offspring (see also Hunt. 1991: Hum and liicher. 1991) . Chromosomal analysis of the female parents indicated no obvious abnormality: however, the L.T male parent contained an abnormal-appearing V chro mosome (V*). Male offspring carrying the Y* chromosome were thereafter mated to LT females to maintain the Y* chromosome on the I T inbred-strain background. For ease of presentation, the large and small marker chromosomes are hereafter desig nated as Xv* and Y * \ respectively.

Two XY* males from the LT-Y* and B6.L I -Y* strains were mated to LT and B6 females, respectively, to obtain segregation data for the Y* chromosome (Table I) . Of the 64 fetuses recov ered from LT-Y* males. 28 were parental type and 36 were recombinant type. O f the 88 fetuses recovered from B6.LT-Y* males. 53 were parental type. 34 were recombinant type. and I was XO. O f the 77 I , live-born offspring analyzed from matings involving (B6 x LT-Y*)F| males mated to B6 females, 44 were parental type. 28 were recombinant type, and 5 were XO. Anal ysis of the combined results indicated no significant deviation from an expected 1:1:1:1 occurrence of XX. XY*, XXY\ and XY** offspring (*--5.89, d f -3. P > 0 .1).

C 'ytological analysis o f V* Mitotic metaphase chromosomes from XY. XY*. and XXV* males and XY*X females were analyzed in G-. C-. and Mu\banded preparations (Fig. I ) . FollowingG-banding. the normal Y chromosome stained more darkly than the other chromo somes. had an indistinct banding pattern, and lacked the ccntromeric heterochromatin characteristic o f the other chromo somes (Fig. le) . A short arm was not discernible in routine Gbanded preparations. By contrast, the Y* chromosome dis played a distinct G-banding pattern and contained extensive Gicmsa-positive centromeric heterochromatin. The size and G-banding pattern of the Y* often resembled that of Chromo some 19 ( Fig. le) . No cytologically detectable short arm was observed, but a darkly stained region was present at the distal end. The Xv* and Y*N chromosomes appeared to be reciprocal products resulting from an unequal exchange between the X and Y* chromosome: The XY* chromosome included the X chromosome attached at its distal end to ail of the Y* chromo some but the centromeric region ( Fig. la. b ). whereas the Y*x chromosome contained the centromeric portion of the Y* chro mosome attached to G-band-negativc material (I ig. le. d). I he Xv* chromosome sometimes displayed a constriction at the junction of the X and Y* chromosomal material (not show n).

Kin. 2. In situ hybridization of various DN'A sequences to mctapha.se chromosomes from XY. XY*. XY**.and XXV* mice. The centromeric end of each chromosome was ascertained by unulysis of the same spreads after Cbanding (data not shown). The Y and Y* chromosomes often stained more intensely with propidiuni iodide than did the other chromosomes. <a-c) Results obtained with MSat5: (a) XY male, hybridization is evident ai the centromeric region of all chromosomes except the Y chromosome (large arrow). Tor all mice examined, the intensity o f hybridization was diminished and subcvnlromericully located on one autosomal pair (small arrows), (b) XY* male: hybridization is evident at the centromeric region of all chromo somes. including the Y* chromosomc(arrow).(c)XY*x female; hybridization is present at the centromeric region o f all chromosomes, including the Y*x chromosome (arrow), (d-f) Results obtained with 70-38: (d> XXV* male: hybridization is apparent ut the subccnlroincrie region of the X (small arrow) and XY* chromosomes (large arrow | and at the centromeric region of two autosomes. probably chromosome pair 11 or 13 (Distcchc ct a!.. 1987). that arc similar in size to the chromosomes containing fewet major satellite sequences (see above), suggesting that they are the same chromosome, (c) XY* male: hybridization is evident at the subccniromcric region of the X chromo some (small arrow) and at the centromeric region of two autosomes. Hybridi zation is not observed on the Y* chromosome (large arrow). (0 XY*X female: hybridization is not observed on the Y*x chromosome (large arrow), although hybridization is evident ai the subccntromeric region of the X chromosome (small arrow) and at the centromeric region o f an autosomal pair, (g-i) Results obtained with Mov-15/1rig) XY male: hybridization is noticeable at the distal end of the ^ long arm (arrow) and at the distal end o f several other chromo somes. (h) XY* male; hybridization is apparent at the proximal region of the Y* chromosome (arrow) and at the distal ends of several other chromosomes, (i) XXV* male: hybridization is evident at the region on the Xv* chromosome where the X and Y chromatin are joined (arrow) and at the distal ends ol several other chromosomes. I he intensity of hybridization to the Y* and XY* chromosomes is diminished compared to that on the normal Y and Y*x (not shown) chromosomes, suggesting that the Y* and X ' ' chromosomes contain fewer Mov-15/1 sequences than docs the normal Y chromosome, (j-l) Results obtained with Ers5A-4/680: (j) XY male, intense hybridization is present at the proximal end o f the Y chromosome (arrow), (k) XY* male: intense hybrid ization is evident at the distal end of the Y* chromosome C-and .'1/i/I-banding showed the presence of a short arm on the normal Y chromosome (Fig. 1 f. g ) but failed to reveal a short arm on the Y* chromosome. The presence of a small, darkly stained region was apparent at the distal end of the Y* and XY* chromosomes (Fig. lg) . C-and /1/id-banding also revealed that the Y* and Y*x chromosomes (as well as the autosomes and X chromosome) contained centromeric heterochromatin (Fig. If.  g ). The presence of extensive /1/id-band-positive material on the Y* and Y*x chromosomes suggested that the centromeric region of the Y* contained major satellite sequences (Kaelbling et al., 1984) . To investigate this possibility, in situ hybridization experiments were conducted using an insert (MSat5) from the pMSat5 clone, which contains major satellite sequences ( Fig. 2a-c) . As expected, in XY males MSat5 hybridized to the centromeric region of all chromosomes except the Y chromo some (Fig. 2a) . By contrast. MSat5 hybridized to the centro meric region of all chromosomes obtained from XY* males, including the Y* chromosome (Fig. 2b) . and to the centromeric region of all chromosomes obtained from X Y*x females, includ ing the Y*x chromosome (Fig. 2c ). For all LT and LT-Y* mice examined, one autosomal pair (probably Chromosome 11 or 13) contained fewer major satellite sequences than the other chro mosomes, and hybridization was subcentromeric (designated by the small arrows in Fig. 2a) .

The X-chromosomal repeat sequence 70-38 was hybridized to chromosomes from X Y* and XXY' males and XY*x females to determine whether the centromere and centromeric hete rochromatin of the Y* chromosome were derived from the X chromosome (Fig. 2d-f ). In the XXY' males, 70-38 hybridized just distal to the centromere on the XY' and X chromosomes and to the centromeric region of a pair of medium-sized chromo somes, possibly Chromosomes 11 or 13 (Disteche et al" 1987) (Fig. 2d) . In XY* males and XY*X females. 70-38 hybridized just distal to the centromeric region of the X chromosome and to the centromeric region of a pair of medium-sized autosomes ( Fig. 2e, 0- To define the position of the pseudoautosomal region of the Y* and XY* chromosomes, a biotinylated insert (Mov-15/1) from pMov-15/1 was hybridized to metaphase preparations from XY, XY*. and XXY* males (Fig. 2g-i) . In XY males, Mov-15/1 hybridized to the distal end of the Y chromosome (Fig. 2g) . whereas in XY* males. Mov-15/1 hybridized to the subcentro meric region of the Y* chromosome (Fig. 2h) . Analysis of meta phase preparations from XXY' males indicated that the XY* chromosome was labeled at the junction of X-and Y*-derived chromatin (Fig. 2i) . The intensity of hybridization signal was diminished on the Y* and XY* chromosomes, as compared to that observed for the Y chromosome. The intensity of hybridi zation signal on the Y*x chromosome was comparable to that observed for the Y chromosome. For all cases analyzed. Mov-15/1 hybridized to the distal ends of at least five other chromo somes. one of which presumably was the X chromosome, as reported by Harbers et al. (1990) .

In situ hybridization was also used to ascertain the position of Y short-arm sequences on the Y* chromosome. Insert from pErs5A-4/680 was chosen for this analysis because it contains 26 and 12 copies of GATA and GACA sequences, respectively, which are amplified on the Y short arm. When hybridized to metaphase preparations from XY. XY*. and XY*X males. Ers5A-4/680 intensely labeled the centromeric region of the Y chromosome ( Fig. 2j ) and the distal end of the Y* and Xv' chro mosomes (Fig. 2k. 1) . Distinct labeling was not evident on any other chromosomes.

Southern-blot analyses were conducted on DN A from female (XX and XY*X) and male (XY. XY*. and XXY') mice using five probes that distinguish Y-specific DNA restriction fragments. The results are presented in Fig. 3 and summarized in Table II . pYBlO and pCRY8/B hybridized to DNA from XY. XY*. and XXY* males but not XX or XY*X females (Fig. 3a. b) . pErs5A-4/680 hybridized to Alu\ fragments shared by both sexes, but only hybridized to the numerous Y-specific Altil fragments in DNA from XY, XY*. and XXY* males (Fig. 3c) . Similarly, pCMPX Y 1 hybridized to the 1,9-kb £coRI fragment from the X chromosome (Zfx) and the 2.1 -kb /tcoRI fragment derived from Chromosome 10 (Zfa) in DNA digests from all individuals, but only hybridized to the male-specific 11.0-kb and 5.0-kb EcoRI fragments (ZJ'y-I and ZJ'y-2. respectively) in DNA digests from X Y. X Y*. and XXY' males (Fig. 3d) . The (TTAGGG)6 telomere consensus probe revealed that DNA from LT females and males contained a number of Hi nil and Dde I fragments shared by both sexes (data not shown). In addition, an 18-kb Hinil male-spe cific telomere-related fragment was present in DNA from XY. XY*. and XXY* males but absent in DNA from XX and XY*X females (Fig. 3e) . Similarly, a 14-kb Dde\ fragment was present in the DNA from XY, XY*. and XXY' males but absent in DNA from XX and XY*X females (data not shown).
body_text.section: Molecular characterization o f the Y* chromosome

body_text.text: We have presented data on the inheritance of a rearranged mouse Y chromosome (Y*), designated T(XAl?;InY)8Ei, which was initially identified in a male from the LT inbred strain. Matings of XY* males to normal females indicated that XY* males produce four types of offspring in equal numbers: normal XX females. XY* males, males containing an excep tionally large chromosome, and females containing an excep tionally small chromosome (Table I ). In addition. XY* males frequently produce XO female offspring. G-banding analysis of the large and small marker chromosomes revealed that the large chromosome (XY') consists of the X chromosome attached at its distal end to the Y* chromosome: the small chromosome (Y*x) consists of the Y* centromere with distal G-band-negative chro matin.

The simplest hypothesis to account for the cytological com position of the XY* and Y*x chromosomes is that the pseudoautosomal region, which is normally located at the distal end of the Y long arm. is positioned just distal to the functional centro mere of the Y* chromosome. As shown in Fig. 4 , a single cross over between a Y chromosome containing a proximally located pseudoautosomal region and a normal X chromosome would generate the XY' and Y*x chromosomes found in offspring of XY* males. G-banding of the XY' and Y*x chromosomes sug gests that recombination between the X and Y* chromosomes occurs between the most distal band of the X chromosome. XF5 (Evans, 1989) . and a position distal to the C-band-positive " + = Present:--absent. h Xv'0 males have been recovered from matings of XO females to X Y* males; one Xv"0 male was fertile.

material of the Y* chromosome. (A diagrammatic interpreta tion of the origin of the Y* chromosome is presented in Fig. 5 and discussed below.) In situ hybridization with Mov-15/1 confirmed that the pseudoautosomal region on the Y* chromosome is located in a different position relative to its location on the normal Y chro mosome. Whereas Mov-15/1 hybridized to the distal end of the Y chromosome, it hybridized to a proximal region of the Y* chromosome just adjacent to the centromere. In addition. Mov-15/1 hybridized to the XY* chromosome at the interface be tween X and Y* chromatin. Hybridization was not observed at the distal end of the Y* or XY' chromosomes. Mov-15/l hybrid ized less intensely to the Y* and XY' chromosomes than to the normal Y and Y*x chromosomes, suggesting that some pseu doautosomal sequences were deleted during the formation of the Y* chromosome.

G-and C-banding indicated that the Y* rearrangement also involved loss of a cytologically detectable Y short arm. How ever. .4/id-banding identified a darkly stained region similar in size to that of the Y short arm region at the distal end of the Y* and XY* chromosomes, suggesting that this region is derived from the Y short arm. This was substantiated by in situ hybridi zation with Ers5A-4/680, which revealed multiple copies of GATA/GACA sequences, normally observed at the proximal end of the Y chromosome, at the distal end of the Y* and XY* chromosomes. Southern-blot analysis with the TTAGGG con sensus telomere sequence further suggested that the normal Y short-arm telomere functions as the Y* distal telomere: The male-specific telomere-related 18-kb Hi nil and 14-kb Dde\ frag ments (see also Elliott and Yen. 1991) are located on the Y* chromosome distal to the pseudoautosomal region, as they are present in XXY* males but absent in XY*X females.

zlM-banding analysis of the Y* chromosome indicated that major satellite sequences were present at the centromeric re gion, a condition not observed in the normal mouse Y chromo- Fig. 4 . Inheritance of the Y* chromosome and its recombinant products with the X chromosome. For ease of presentation, the size of the pseudoautosomal regions is exaggerated. The centromeres are represented as circles, with the Y* centromere filled to indicate acquisition from another chromosome. The solid section represents acquired centromeric heterochromatin. The diagonally hatched segment represents the pseudoautosomal region, while the horizontally hatched segment represents the region derived from the Y short arm. An x represents a crossover between the X and Y* chromosomes. A single crossover between the X and the Y* chromosomes accounts for the recovery of four types of offspring in equal frequencies from matings involv ing normal XX females and XY* males: nonrccombinant XX females and XY* males and recombinant XY*X females and XXY" males. Fig. 5 . Model explaining the origin of the Y* chromosome. For ease of presentation, the length of the pseudoautosomal region is exaggerated, and the pseudoautosomal region is divided into four segments, 1-4. In this hypothesis, Y* resulted from three chromosomal breaks: one break occurred within or just distal to the centromeric heterochromatin (CH) of an unknown chromosome, and two breaks occurred in the Y chromosome long arm. one at the distal end of the pseudoautosomal (PA) region (diagonally hatched), between segments 3 and 4 (Break I). and one between segments I and 2 (Break 2). near the junction of the long-arm sequences and the PA region. The cen tromere (filled circle) and CH (solid-black segment) from the unknown chro mosome then attached to the broken PA region of the Y chromosome contain ing segments 2-3 (at Break 2). and the remainder of the Y chromosome (the short arm [horizontally hatched], centromere [open circle], and remainder of the Y long arm. minus the PA segment 4) attached to the broken end of the PA region at segment 3 (Break I). Segment 4. including the pseudoautosomal telomere, was probably deleted. Deletion of PA segment 4 would account for the observed reduction in Mov-15/l hybridization to the Y* chromosome, compared to that on the normal Y chromosome. Inversion of PA segments 2 and 3 occurred during the rearrangement of Y-chromosoma! material. Inver sion of the majority of the PA region would maintain polarity between the PA region of the X and Y* chromosomes, and recombination within this region would account for the recovery of the XY* and Y*x chromosomes from XY* males. However, segment I of the PA region is shown not inverted, as this would allow for inverted pairing and recombination between the X and Y* chromosomes, as indicated by the presence of a dicentric sex chromosome or an acentric fragment in 10% of meiotic metaphase II cells from XY* males (see Hale el al.. 1991) . The original Y centromere is shown in gray to denote it being present but inactivated (gray). some. In situ hybridization with MSat5 confirmed the presence of major satellite sequences at the centromeric end of the Y* chromosome, indicating that they were acquired from another chromosome. Presumably, the functional centromere of Y* is also derived from the chromosome that donated the C-bandpositive material.
9 X x O O 9 X X Y X Y O O f î t

In situ hybridization experiments were conducted with the X-chromosome sequence 70-38 to ascertain whether the cen tromere and centromeric heterochromatin of Y* were derived from the X chromosome. This probe detects multicopy se quences located just distal to the region comprising the major satellite sequences on the X chromosome (Disteche et al., 1987 (Disteche et al., , 1989 . Following hybridization, 70-38 sequences were present adjacent to the centromeric region of the XY* chromo some but not on the Y* or Y*x chromosomes. Thus, if the X chromosome is the origin of the Y* functional centromere and centromeric heterochromatin, the X-chromosomal breakpoint must have occurred proximal to the 70-38 sequences. Although the chromosomal origin of the centromere and centromeric heterochromatin (major satellite sequence) on the Y* chromo some remains unknown, the X chromosome seems a likely source of these sequences. Analysis of synaptonemal complexes in XY* males revealed that the centromeric region of the Y* chromosome is often associated with the centromeric region of the X chromosome (see the accompanying paper [Hale et al.. 1991] ). suggesting homology between these chromosomal seg ments. The hypothesized source of the Y* centromere and cen tromeric heterochromatin is indicated in the nomenclature by the designation "X A 1 ?". indicating that the donor chromosome is presumed, but not proven, to be the X chromosome.

Southern-blot analysis was used to determine whether se quences normally present on the mouse Y short arm are present on the Y* chromosome. The finding of male-specific GATA/GACA sequences together with Zfy-1 and ZJ'y-2 se quences and pCRY8/B hybridizing sequences in DNA from XY* males indicate that these short arm-derived sequences are present on the Y* chromosome. The presence of these sequences in DNA from XX Y' males and their absence in DNA from XY*X females indicate that these sequences reside on the Y* chromo some distal to the pseudoautosomal region, a finding concor dant with results of in situ hybridization using Ers5A-4/680. XXY' mice develop as H-Y positive males, while XY*X mice develop as H-Y negative females (Simpson et al.. 1983) . indicat ing that the Tdy and Hya loci are also located distal to the pseu doautosomal region on the Y* chromosome (see Table II ). Finally, the pYBlO probe produced normal male hybridization patterns in XY. XY*. and XXY' DNA and failed to hybridize to XX and XY*X DNA. indicating that YB10 sequences are present on the Y* chromosome at a position distal to the pseu doautosomal region.

In Fig. 5 we have diagrammed a hypothesis to account for the derivation of the Y* chromosome. We propose that the Y* chro mosome originated as a consequence of three chromosomal breaks. One break occurred in a chromosome, possibly the X chromosome, at a position within or just distal to the centro meric heterochromatin, and two breaks occurred in the pseu doautosomal region of the Y chromosome. Joining of the broken ends resulted in inversion of the majority of the pseu doautosomal region and attachment of this region to the for eign-derived chromosomal segment containing a centromere and centromeric heterochromatin. In addition, a distally posi tioned Y-chromosomal segment (possibly including the pseudoautosomal telomere) was lost. Thus, the newly formed Y* chromosome contains all of the Y-specific regions intact, with the short-arm region now positioned at the distal end and the pseudoautosomal region located interstitially. just distal to the newly acquired centromere. This model also includes reten tion of the original Y centromere: however, the mitotic stability of the Y* chromosome and the presence of a single primary con striction proximal to the acquired centromeric heterochromatin suggest that the original Y centromere is nonfunctional. (There is precedent for the occurrence of stable dicentric mammalian chromosomes by inactivation of one centromere [e.g.. Earnshaw and Migeon. 1985: Peretti et al., 1986; Therman et al., 1986 : Earnshaw et al.. 1989 : Wandall. 1989 Haaf and Schmid, 1990: Maraschio et al., 1990] .) It could be argued that the Y centro mere was deleted during the formation of the Y*: however, two additional Y chromosomal breakpoints would be requiredone on the short arm just above the centromere and one on the long arm distal to the centromere.

In the proposed model, the majority of the pseudoautosomal region (Fig. 5, regions 2 and 3) is shown inverted to maintain the proper pairing between the X and Y* pseudoautosomal regions during pachynema and to account for the recovery of offspring carrying the X/Y* reciprocal recombinant products. However, a segment of the pseudoautosomal region (region 1) is shown noninverted. Retaining a noninverted segment of the pseudoauto somal region would allow inverted pairing and recombination to occur between the X and Y* chromosomes and result in the formation of a dicentric sex chromosome or an acentric frag ment. observed in approximately 10% of metaphase II cells from XY* males (see the accompanying paper [Hale et al., 1991] ). Zygotes receiving the dicentric (or broken) sex chromo some or acentric fragment would develop as XO females, which, in fact, are frequently recovered from matings involving XY* males.

Several questions remain concerning the origin of the Y* chromosome. Identification and analysis of pseudoautosomalderived restriction fragments in normal LT versus LT-Y* males would confirm whether a segment of the Y* pseudoautosomal region, including the pseudoautosomal telomere, was deleted during the formation of the Y* chromosome. Analysis of these sequences could also be informative in determining whether a segment of the Y* pseudoautosomal region is noninverted. Fur ther analysis using a centromere-specific detection system (Moroi et al., 1980; Merry et al., 1985) is needed to confirm the hypothesis that the Y* chromosome contains the Y centromere in an inactive state. Finally, identification of the chromosomal origin of the centromere and centromeric heterochromatin of the Y* chromosome awaits the availability of chromosome-spe cific centromeric probes for mouse chromosomes.

Miklos (1974) . Burgoyne (1982) , and Burgoyne and Baker (1984) have argued that primary spermatocytes containing uni valent X and Y chromosomes do not contribute to the func tional sperm pool and hypothesized that X-Y pairing is a prereq uisite for completion of male meiosis. Evans et al. (1982) pre sented a similar hypothesis, suggesting that a reciprocal ex change between the X and Y chromosomes is a regular and nec essary requirement for the production of functional sperm. Meiotic and segregation data from S.\T-carrier males (Cattanach et al.. 1971 : Keitges et al.. 1987 and XY* males support the X-Y crossover hypothesis. For example, whereas 80% of diakinesis and metaphase I cells in XY* males contain unival ent, nonrecombinant sex chromosomes. 100% of the metaphase II cells in XY* males contain recombinant sex chromosomes (Hale et al.. 1991) . This apparent discrepancy is resolved, how ever, if germ cells in which X-Y* recombination had not occurred are eliminated between metaphase I and metaphase II. This explanation is also concordant with our finding that XY* males sire equal numbers of recombinant and nonrecombinant progeny. Whether X-Y pairing per se or X-Y recombination is a prerequisite for production of functional sperm in normal XY male mice still needs to be confirmed and awaits identification of pseudoautosomal markers for assessing recombination.

The Y* chromosome and ils recombinant products with the X chromosome can be utilizxd to address a variety of biological and genetic questions. For example, the XY' chromosome is sig nificantly larger than Chromosome 1. Because it can be readily identified in nonbanded metaphasc preparations, its use would facilitate the ordering of X-linked loci by in situ hybridization. In addition, the XY" chromosome can be readily separated from the rest of the chromosomal complement by flow sorting, there by expediting the construction of DNA libraries with enriched X-and Y-derived sequences. The Y*x chromosome has already proven a useful tool. Because XY*X females have a high fre quency of sex-chromosome nondisjunction, patroclinous XO females can be routinely recovered from matings involving XY*X females (Hunt. 1991) . Furthermore, approximately 33% of the offspring of XY*X females are XYY*X males (Hunt and Eicher. 1991) . When these males are mated to normal females, 25% of the offspring are XXY males, making it now relatively easy to produce these previously rare males for study. Finally, meiotic and segregation analysis of XYY*X males has led to the interesting observation that, compared with the normal Y chro mosome. the Y*x chromosome preferentially pairs with the X chromosome (Hunt and Eicher. 1991) . The basis for the ability of the small Y*x chromosome to outcompete the Y chromo some for pairing with the X chromosome awaits further study.

Rudolf Jaenisch for pMov-15/1. and Janet Rossant for pMSatS. We thank Marie Ivey and Michelle Higgins for preparing geno mic DNAs. and Meredith Hamilton for advice on fluorescence in situ hybrid ization. We are also indebted to Paul Burgovne. Muriel Davisson. Ira Grecnbaum .and Ken Paigen for their critical comm ents on an earlier version of this manuscript. We especially want to thank Rosemary Elliott for sharing unpub lished information on telomere-related sequences present in C57BL/6J mice.
